Name: Hadamard
Description: Let f be a smooth, real-valued function defined on an open, star-convex neighborhood U of a point a in n-dimensional Euclidean space. Then f(x) can be expressed, for all x in U, in the form: f(x)=f(a)+sum_{i=1}^n (x_i-a_i) g_i(x), where each gi is a smooth function on U, a = (a1,...,an), and x = (x1,...,xn)

Name: Star domain
Description: In mathematics, a set S in the Euclidean space Rn is called a star domain (or star-convex set, star-shaped or radially convex set) if there exists x0 in S such that for all x in S the line segment from x0 to x is in S

Name: Euclidean space
Description: Euclidean space encompasses the two-dimensional Euclidean plane, the three-dimensional space of Euclidean geometry, and certain other spaces

Name: Plane
Description: A plane is a flat, two-dimensional surface

Name: Surface
Description: A surface is a two-dimensional, topological manifold

Name: Vector space
Description: A vector space (also called a linear space) is a collection of objects called vectors, which may be added together and multiplied ("scaled") by numbers, called scalars in this context

Name: Vector
Description: An element of a vector space

Name: Scalar
Description: In linear algebra, real numbers are called scalars and relate to vectors in a vector space through the operation of scalar multiplication, in which a vector can be multiplied by a number to produce another vector

Name: Heine-Cantor
Description: If f : M->N is a continuous function between two metric spaces, and M is compact, then f is uniformly continuous. An important special case is that every continuous function from a closed interval to the real numbers is uniformly continuous

Name: Continuous function
Description: A continuous function is, roughly speaking, a function for which small changes in the input result in small changes in the output

Name: Compact space
Description: Compactness is a property that generalizes the notion of a subset of Euclidean space being closed (that is, containing all its limit points) and bounded (that is, having all its points lie within some fixed distance of each other)

Name: Borel
Description: Suppose U is an open set in the Euclidean space Rn, and suppose that f0, f1 ... is a sequence of smooth functions on U. If I is an any open interval in R containing 0 (possibly I = R), then there exists a smooth function F(t, x) defined on IxU, such that ... for k >= 0 and x in U

Name: Open set
Description: In topology, an open set is an abstract concept generalizing the idea of an open interval in the real line

Name: Beer
Description: if (X, d) is a complete, separable metric space, then Cl(X) with the Wijsman topology is a Polish space, i.e. it is separable and metrizable with a complete metric

Name: Metric space
Description: A metric space is a set for which distances between all members of the set are defined. Those distances, taken together, are called a metric on the set

Name: Admissible unlabelled constructions
Description: The constructions of union, cartesian product, sequence, multiset, powerset, and cycle are all admissible. The associated operators are ... The sequence, cycle, and set translations necessitate that Bo = 0. The class ... consisting of the neutral object only, and the class Z consisting of a single "atomic" object (node, letter) of size 1 have OGFs

Name: Symbolic method, unlabelled case
Description: The generating function of a constructible class is a component of a system of generating function equations whose terms are built from ... The operator Q translating sequences (Seq) is classically known as the quasi-inverse. The operator Exp (multisets, MSET) is called the Polya exponential 2 and Exp (powersets, PSet) is the modified Polya exponential. The operator Log is the Polya logarithm. They are named after Polya who first developed the general enumerative theory of objects under permutation groups

Name: Implicit specifications
Description: The generating functions associated to the implicit equations in X ... are respectively where Li(k) is the Mobius function

Name: Theorem 19.1.
Description: The sum of the widths of the strips is not less than 2.

Name: Theorem 19.2.
Description: If the curve 7 is bounded, that is, lies in a disc of some radius r, centered at the origin, then n 7 ((p,p) = for p > r, and hence the integral has a finite value.

Name: Curve
Description: a curve (also called a curved line in older texts) is, generally speaking, an object similar to a line but which is not required to be straight

Name: Theorem 19.5.
Description: The average absolute curvature of T is not greater than the average absolute curvature of 7.

Name: Theorem 20.1.
Description: Let P be a convex n-gon on the unit sphere, A its area and ai, . . . , a n its angles. Then A = ai - h a n - (n - 2)tt.

Name: Angle
Description: An angle is the figure formed by two rays, called the sides of the angle, sharing a common endpoint, called the vertex of the angle

Name: Theorem 20.3.
Description: The angle a(j) equals the sum of curvatures of the vertices of P that lie in the domain bounded by 7.

Name: Theorem 21.1.
Description: Let P be a convex polyhedron whose vertices are colored black and white so that there are more black vertices and no two black vertices are adjacent. Then P cannot be inscribed into a sphere.

Name: Polyhedron
Description: A polyhedron (plural polyhedra or polyhedrons) is a solid in three dimensions with flat polygonal faces, straight edges and sharp corners or vertices

Name: Wallace, Bolyai, Gerwien
Description: Let Pi and P 2 be two plane polygons of the same area. Then it is possible to cut Pi into pieces by straight lines and to reassemble these pieces as P2

Name: Polygon
Description: A polygon is traditionally a plane figure that is bounded by a finite chain of straight line segments closing in a loop to form a closed chain or circuit

Name: Theorem 22.2.
Description: Let C and T be a cube and a regular tetrahedron of the same volume. Suppose that each of them is cut into the same number of pieces by planes. It is not possible that the two collections of (polyhedral) pieces are the same.

Name: Tetrahedron
Description: a tetrahedron (plural: tetrahedra or tetrahedrons) is a polyhedron composed of four triangular faces, three of which meet at each corner or vertex. It has six edges and four vertices
